metadata.title: AI-Native Engineering Maturity Assessment
metadata.description: 14 situational-judgment maturity questions across 7 capabilities + 8 market research questions
metadata.framingText: Pick the option closest to your current practice — there are no right or wrong answers. This is about where you are today, not where you want to be.

screening.prompt: Do you currently use any AI tools in your development work?

fallbackResult.name: Pre-Explorer
fallbackResult.description: You haven't started using AI in your development work yet — and that's okay. The AI-native engineering landscape is evolving fast, and there's never been a better time to start exploring.

capabilities.name: Spec-Driven Development
capabilities.description: How you define, structure, and maintain specifications that drive AI-assisted development

capabilities.name: Context Management
capabilities.description: How your AI tools access, retain, and evolve project knowledge

capabilities.name: Agent Collaboration
capabilities.description: How AI agents participate in and coordinate across your development workflow

capabilities.name: Observability & Feedback Learning
capabilities.description: How you measure, track, and learn from AI performance in your workflow

capabilities.name: Governance & Trust
capabilities.description: How you ensure quality, safety, and trustworthiness of AI-generated outputs

capabilities.name: Continuous Specification & Delivery
capabilities.description: How connected and automated the path is from requirements to production

capabilities.name: Organizational Adaptation
capabilities.description: How your team or organization has evolved its structure and practices around AI

archetypes.name: The Explorer
archetypes.tagline: The AI revolution hasn't hit your workflow yet
archetypes.description: You're aware of AI coding tools and have started experimenting, but AI isn't yet a consistent part of how you work. You're in discovery mode — trying things out, seeing what sticks.
archetypes.growthFocus: Pick one task you do daily and try using AI for it consistently for two weeks. Build the habit before expanding scope.

archetypes.name: The Adopter
archetypes.tagline: AI assists you, but you're still in the driver's seat
archetypes.description: AI has found a place in your workflow — you use it for specific tasks and it genuinely helps. But you're still doing most of the orchestration, context management, and quality control manually.
archetypes.growthFocus: Start writing structured specifications before coding. Give AI more context upfront and let it do more of the heavy lifting on implementation.

archetypes.name: The Integrator
archetypes.tagline: AI is embedded in your workflow — you'd feel the loss
archetypes.description: AI is a core part of how you build software. You have established practices, your tools work together, and you'd significantly feel the impact if AI was removed from your workflow.
archetypes.growthFocus: Focus on connecting your tools and building feedback loops. Invest in context management so AI can do more with less manual setup.

archetypes.name: The Conductor
archetypes.tagline: Your agents do the work, you set the direction
archetypes.description: You've moved beyond using AI as an assistant — you're orchestrating AI workflows, maintaining rich context, and focusing your energy on direction-setting and quality oversight.
archetypes.growthFocus: Build automated feedback loops and invest in observability. Let your systems learn from outcomes and self-improve.

archetypes.name: The Architect
archetypes.tagline: You're defining how the industry builds with AI
archetypes.description: Your engineering practice is fully AI-native. Specs drive delivery, context flows seamlessly, feedback loops close automatically, and your systems continuously evolve. You're not just using AI — you're pioneering how it's used.
archetypes.growthFocus: Share what you've built. Write about your workflows, contribute to open-source tooling, and help others reach this level.

maturityQuestions.prompt: When you start building a new feature, how do you define what needs to be built?

answers.text: I describe it in a ticket, chat, or conversation — enough for me to start coding
I write a structured spec that AI agents can read and execute from directly
I set the goal and agents write, evolve, and maintain the spec as they build

maturityQuestions.prompt: How do your specifications relate to your running code?

answers.text: They're separate — specs live in docs, code lives in the repo
They're connected — I can trace code back to the original requirement
They co-evolve — when code changes, specs update automatically and vice versa

maturityQuestions.prompt: How do your AI tools get context about your project?

answers.text: I paste relevant code or docs into the chat each time I need help
I maintain context files and rules that AI tools can reference automatically
Context is shared across tools and sessions — I never re-explain my project

maturityQuestions.prompt: What happens to the knowledge generated during a coding session?

answers.text: It's mostly lost — each session starts fresh
I capture important findings in project files for the team to reuse
The system remembers and connects new knowledge to existing context automatically

maturityQuestions.prompt: How do AI tools fit into your daily development workflow?

answers.text: I use AI for occasional help — autocomplete, chat questions, code snippets
AI handles specific tasks in my workflow — tests, docs, code reviews, or generation
Multiple agents coordinate on complex tasks end-to-end with minimal direction from me

maturityQuestions.prompt: When a task involves multiple steps, how do AI agents participate?

answers.text: I do each step myself and ask AI for help on individual pieces
AI handles specific steps, but I coordinate the overall process
I describe the end goal and agents orchestrate the full process

maturityQuestions.prompt: How do you know if AI is actually helping your development process?

answers.text: Gut feeling — I notice when it helps or fails, but don't measure it
I have visibility into AI performance and review it regularly
The system tracks AI performance and automatically adjusts when it underperforms

maturityQuestions.prompt: What happens when an AI-generated output fails or produces a bug?

answers.text: I fix it manually and move on
I update my context, prompts, or rules to prevent the same failure next time
The system detects failure patterns and adapts automatically — it learns without my intervention

maturityQuestions.prompt: How do you ensure AI-generated code is safe and correct before it ships?

answers.text: I review it myself — same as any code review
Documented guidelines and automated checks validate AI output quality
Agents audit each other's work with automated verification — every decision is traceable

maturityQuestions.prompt: When AI produces code you don't fully understand, what do you do?

answers.text: I rewrite it — I need to understand every line
I validate it against the spec and tests — if it passes checks, I accept it
I trust the verification pipeline — agents check each other and flag what needs human review

maturityQuestions.prompt: How connected is the path from your requirements to production deployment?

answers.text: Loosely — I write code, run tests, and deploy with mostly manual steps
Specs feed into the pipeline and trigger relevant automation
One change flows through everything — specs, code, tests, infra, and docs evolve together

maturityQuestions.prompt: How do changes in requirements flow through to your delivered software?

answers.text: I manually update code, tests, and docs when requirements change
Requirement changes trigger automated updates to related tests and tasks
Agents propagate changes through code, tests, infra, and docs without my intervention

maturityQuestions.prompt: How has AI changed the way you or your team organizes work?

answers.text: It hasn't really — individuals experiment on their own
Workflows have been redesigned to include AI as a core part of how we work
Team structure and processes are continuously reshaped based on what AI makes possible

maturityQuestions.prompt: How does your organization invest in AI capabilities for engineering?

answers.text: No formal investment — tool access is individual choice
Dedicated budget for AI tools, training, and process integration
AI capability is a strategic priority — it shapes hiring, performance reviews, and team goals

marketResearchQuestions.prompt: Which AI coding tools do you actively use?
How often do you use AI tools in development?
What do you primarily use AI for?
What's the biggest friction in your AI coding workflow?
options: AI doesn't understand my codebase well enough

marketResearchQuestions.prompt: If you could add one capability to your AI setup, what would it be?
How much do you spend on AI coding tools per month?
